alert_name: SMB-Based Lateral Movement to Finance File Server
description: Cortex XDR detected AdaptixC2 beacon attempting lateral movement from compromised workstation FIN-WKS-087 to finance file server FS-PROD-01 via SMB protocol, representing post-exfiltration persistence and expansion phase. Network anomaly detection identified suspicious SMB traffic pattern inconsistent with normal user file access: (1) 06:24 AM - Initial SMB connection FIN-WKS-087 → FS-PROD-01:445 originating from malicious rundll32.exe process (PID 9156) rather than Windows Explorer, (2) Authentication using legitimate rbrown@financialcorp.com credentials (harvested during earlier credential theft phase), (3) SMB tree connect to hidden administrative share \\FS-PROD-01\ADMIN$ (system administrators only - privilege escalation), (4) Remote service creation via Service Control Manager (SCM) protocol uploading malicious executable 'WindowsDefenderUpdate.exe' to C:\Windows\Temp\, (5) Service registered as 'WDUpdateSvc' with auto-start configuration, (6) Remote service execution launching AdaptixC2 beacon on file server establishing independent C2 channel. EDR behavioral analysis on FS-PROD-01 detected beacon execution: WindowsDefenderUpdate.exe (45KB PE executable, hash: 9f3e7b5a1d8c4e2f6a9b0d3c5e7f1a4b) executed at 06:27 AM, process immediately connected to tech-system[.]online establishing C2 heartbeat, memory injection into legitimate svchost.exe process for stealth, registry persistence created (HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\WDUpdateSvc), beacon implemented named pipe communication \\pipe\winsock_event_notifier for inter-process signaling. Attack analysis reveals sophisticated lateral movement technique: (1) Abuse of legitimate SMB administrative shares avoiding file copy detection, (2) Service creation mimics Windows Defender update process (naming convention, Temp directory location), (3) Rapid execution minimizing detection window (3-minute installation), (4) Independent beacon on file server provides redundancy if FIN-WKS-087 remediated, (5) File server compromise enables organization-wide data access (2.3TB financial archives, 847 users home directories). Threat intelligence confirms AdaptixC2 framework includes automated lateral movement module targeting administrative shares, service creation via SCM protocol, and multi-host beacon deployment for persistence. Impact assessment: CRITICAL - file server compromise provides attacker access to complete financial department data repository, ability to stage ransomware deployment across network, potential for domain-wide compromise if domain admin credentials harvested from FS-PROD-01 memory. EDR correlation shows attack progression: social engineering (T1566) → execution (T1059) → persistence (T1543) → credential access (T1003) → discovery (T1482) → collection (T1005) → exfiltration (T1041) → lateral movement (T1021.002) - complete MITRE ATT&CK kill chain executed.
policy_description: SMB lateral movement to file server via administrative share with service persistence
policy_recommendation: CRITICAL: Isolate FS-PROD-01 immediately (network-level containment), stop WDUpdateSvc service and delete WindowsDefenderUpdate.exe, remove HKLM service registry key, terminate all SMB sessions from FIN-WKS-087, disable ADMIN$ share access for non-privileged users, reset rbrown@financialcorp.com credentials, hunt for additional lateral movement (search: SMB connections to ADMIN$ from non-admin accounts), deploy Group Policy: RestrictAnonymous=2, RequireSecuritySignature=enabled, enable SMB signing mandatory, implement privileged access management (PAM) for administrative share access, enable Microsoft Advanced Threat Analytics for lateral movement detection, forensically image FS-PROD-01 for incident response analysis, review all file server access logs for unauthorized data access post-compromise, consider domain-wide credential reset if domain admin credentials potentially compromised, engage external incident response for containment strategy
mitre_att&ck_technique: T1021.002 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
